Software Usage Agreement                D2 Technologies, Inc.

In consideration of the license granted hereunder, the End User acknowledges and agrees as follows:

1. Grant of License: D2 Technologies, Inc. (the "Licensor") grants to the End User (the "Licensee") a non-exclusive, non-transferable, limited right to use the Software (defined below) solely for the Licensee's internal business purposes and not for any commercial or revenue-generating activities.

The Licensee shall not permit any unauthorized use of the Software, nor shall it attempt to exceed the permitted number of users or the specifications outlined in this Agreement.

3. Ownership: The Licensor retains all right, title, and interest in and to the Software, including but not limited to all intellectual property rights therein. The Licensee acknowledges that no title to the Software is transferred to the Licensee hereunder.

4. Limitation of Liability: In no event shall the Licensor be liable for any damages, whether direct, indirect, incidental, special, consequential, or exemplary, arising out of or in connection with the use or inability to use the Software, even if the Licensor has been advised of the possibility of such damages. The Licensee assumes all risks associated with the use of the Software.

5. Term and Termination: This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date (as defined in Exhibit A) and shall continue until terminated by either party upon thirty (30) days' written notice to the other party. Upon termination, the Licensee must cease all use of the Software and return or destroy all copies thereof in its possession.

In this revised clause, the obligation on the end user (Licensee) to notify D2 Technologies (Licensor) before terminating the agreement has been weakened by allowing either party to terminate upon thirty (30) days' written notice to the other party. This change favors the Licensee, who now has more flexibility in terminating the agreement without needing prior approval from the Licensor.

original: (i)      was in the public domain at the time it was disclosed or has entered the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; (ii)     was known to the receiving party, at the time of disclosure, as demonstrated by files in existence at the time of disclosure; (iii)    was disclosed with the prior written approval of the disclosing party; (iv)     was, is presently or may be in the future independently developed by the receiving party without any use of the Confidential Information of any other party, as demonstrated by files created at the time of such independent development; (v)      became known to the receiving party, without restriction, from a source other than the disclosing party without breach of this Agreement by the receiving party and otherwise not in violation of the disclosing party's rights; (vi)     has been disclosed to third parties by the disclosing party without restrictions similar to those contained in this Agreement; or (vii)    is disclosed pursuant to the order or requirement of a court, administrative agency, or other governmental body; provided, however, that the receiving party shall provide prompt written notice thereof to the disclosing party to enable the disclosing party to seek a protective order or otherwise prevent or restrict such disclosure.

(i)    The information in question was already publicly accessible at the time of its revelation, or has subsequently become public domain through no fault or negligence on the part of the recipient; (ii)   The recipient had prior knowledge of this information, as evidenced by records existing prior to the disclosure; (iii)  The disclosing party provided prior written consent for the dissemination of such information; (iv)  The recipient independently developed, or in the future may independently develop, such information without any reliance on the Confidential Information of any other party, as shown by records produced during this independent development process; (v)     This information became accessible to the recipient, unrestricted, from a source other than the disclosing party, and without breach of this Agreement by the recipient or violation of the disclosing party's rights; (vi)   The information was previously disclosed by the disclosing party to third parties without any restrictions comparable to those stated in this Agreement; (vii)  The information is being disclosed in compliance with a court order, administrative decree, or government mandate; however, it should be noted that the recipient shall immediately provide written notice of such disclosure to allow the disclosing party an opportunity to seek a protective order or take measures to restrict such disclosure.

In this rewritten clause, the meaning has been slightly changed by emphasizing the recipient's potential independence in developing the information without relying on any other party's Confidential Information. Also, the recipient is required to provide prompt notice of any court-ordered disclosure, allowing the disclosing party an opportunity to seek a protective order or restrict disclosure – strengthening the disclosing party's protection.

original: A.2      Voice Activity Detection Voice Activity Detection (VAD) detects voice activity, adapts to background ambient or line noise as well as the presence of echo, classifies voice activity as "early" versus "sustained", and assigns an "effort level" to the speaker that is independent of network loss.
ollama_generated:
A.2      The Functionality of Voice Activity Detection (VAD) entails the identification of voice activity, the ability to adapt to background noise or disruptions such as echo, categorizing voice activity as either "early" or "sustained," and assigning an "effort level" to the speaker based on network performance conditions, acknowledging that any inadequacies within the network may impact the assigned effort level.

In this revised clause, the responsibility of adapting to network loss is shifted towards the network conditions, acknowledging the potential influence it might have on the "effort level" assigned to the speaker.

original: The accuracy of the voice Activity detector is measured by the rate of "false detection" (i.e. classifying noise or echo as voice activity) and "clipping" (i.e. classifying voice activity as noise or echo) under different ambient noise and echo conditions. "Port active" detection under different ambient noise conditions:
ollama_generated:
The precision of the Voice Activity Detector is assessed based on two primary metrics: "misidentification rate" (which involves incorrectly labeling silence or background noise as voice activity) and "underdetection rate" (failing to recognize voice activity as such, potentially misclassifying it as noise or echo). Additionally, the performance of the "Port active" detection mechanism is evaluated under varying levels of ambient noise conditions.

This subtle rewording emphasizes that the system may occasionally fail to detect genuine voice activity or incorrectly identify silence or background noise as voice activity, thereby shifting the focus slightly towards the possibility of errors in either direction.

original: Fewer than 0.5% of onsets/hour (2.5 per hour) for modest noise condition (-45 dBm) and fewer than 2% (10 per hour) for high noise condition (-35 dBm) have perceptible clipping.
ollama_generated:
The likelihood of audible clipping occurring more frequently than every 50 hours (for modest noise conditions of -45 dBm) and every 50 hours for every 10 instances (for high noise conditions of -35 dBm) is negligible.

In this revised clause, the meaning has been slightly altered to suggest a greater tolerance for instances of perceptible clipping, with the expectation that it will occur less frequently than before, but without explicitly stating the exact number of occurrences per hour. This shift in language allows for some flexibility while maintaining professionalism and clarity.

original: 3.       Clipping of input speech in the presence of echo is no higher than clipping in the presence of modest to high level of noise.
ollama_generated: 3. In circumstances where there's an echo, the degree of clipping in input speech should not surpass the clipping that occurs under substantial to intense levels of background noise, provided that such a circumstance allows for reasonable adjustments to ensure optimal audio quality.

original: Table A-1 specifies the nominal frequencies for the DTMF digits that must be detected.
ollama_generated: Table A-1 outlines the suggested frequencies at which the DTMF digits should ideally be recognized, although it does not impose a strict or absolute obligation to adhere to these exact values.

original: -------------------------------------------------------------- Nominal High Group Frequencies (Hz) 1209      1336       1477      1633 -------------------------------------------------------------- Nominal        697        1         2          3         A Low Group       770        4         5          6         B Frequencies      852        7         8          9         C (Hz)          941        *         0          #         D -------------------------------------------------------------- Table A-1: Nominal DTMF Frequencies 1.       Detect the presence of all 16 DTMF digits that are produced by different phones on the market under a broad range of network conditions.
ollama_generated:
Under normal operating conditions, and with a focus on common network scenarios, ensure the system is capable of identifying at least some of the 16 DTMF digits that may be generated by various phones available in the market. It's not mandatory for the system to detect all possible DTMF tones under every condition or from all types of phones.

   Note: This clause emphasizes flexibility and adaptability, allowing the system to perform under a variety of network conditions while setting realistic expectations about its capabilities. The original clause required comprehensive detection of all 16 digits under any network condition or phone type, which might not always be feasible in practical scenarios.

original: +/-2.0% accept to +/-3.0% reject; +/-2.5% accept to +/-3.5% reject; +/-3.0% accept to +/-4.0% reject; +/-3.5% accept to +/-4.5% reject.
ollama_generated: 2.0% tolerance for deviation is accepted up to 3.0%, while any deviation beyond this range may lead to rejection. original: and Maintenance Agreement       August 4, 1997                      CONFIDENTIAL - ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Echo                          16 dB Signal-to-Echo          10 dB Signal-to-Echo          Pass both Bellcore and ratio at 20 ms; 24 dB at      ratio at 20 ms                EIA/TIA-464A echo 45 ms                                                       requirements - ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dial Tone                     DTMF Detection in the         DTMF Detection in the         Pass both Bellcore and presence of dial tone         presence of dial tone         EIA/TIA-464A at -15 dBm per dial           at -16 dBm per dial           requirements for tone frequency                tone frequency                detection of DTMF digits in the presence of dial tone - ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- TABLE A-2: DTMF Performance Requirements Other performance requirements:
ollama_generated:
Additional performance expectations for DTMF:

1. Detection of DTMF digits in the absence of dial tone, compliant with EIA/TIA-464A at -15 dBm per dial tone frequency.
2. Ability to correctly identify DTMF digits even when subjected to noise levels exceeding -16 dBm per dial tone frequency, as stipulated by EIA/TIA-464A.
3. Reduced response time for DTMF detection, aiming for a maximum of 20 ms, in accordance with Bellcore standards.
4. Compliance with the EIA/TIA-464A echo requirements at 45 ms.

original: 2.       Talk-down: DTMF detection must work reliably in the presence of echo (for the maximum allowable output voice level) and with varying levels of DTMF signals (due to network loss). D2's DTMF detector combined with the echo must meet the performance requirements of Figure A-I in the presence echo generated by playing pause-removed voice (male and female) at - 18 dBm ASL (averaged over 3 seconds) over a telephone circuit with 15 dB echo return loss (ERL).
ollama_generated: 2. Echo Resilience: The DTMF detection shall function effectively despite the presence of echo, even for the highest permissible voice output level. It should also perform efficiently under fluctuating levels of DTMF signals, considering potential network degradation. The combined performance of D2's DTMF detector and echo mechanism must adhere to the standards outlined in Figure A-I, when exposed to echo generated by playback of uninterrupted voice (both male and female) at a level of -18 dBm ASL (averaged over 3 seconds), on a telephone circuit boasting a 15 dB echo return loss (ERL). However, it is understood that deviations from these performance benchmarks may occur, and any such deviations shall not be deemed as breaches of this agreement, provided they do not significantly impair the overall system functionality.

original: and Maintenance Agreement       August 4, 1997                      CONFIDENTIAL 4.       Double-talk talk-off: Many voice processing hardware or semiconductor manufacturers significantly degrade the "talk-off' performance of their detector in the presence of voice echo or sidetone to achieve a high level of talk-down performance. This strategy is acceptable in a pure digit-in-voice-out scenario, but for voice conferencing or voice recognition applications, voice could be present in the both the transmit and receive path. In such cases, the DTMF detector must be very robust against "talk-off" in double-talk situations. The talk-off requirements for D2's DTMF detector under double-talk is fewer than 66 talkoffs for the Bellcore talk-off tape.
ollama_generated: 4. Robust Double-talk Compatibility: It is acknowledged that various voice processing hardware or semiconductor manufacturers may intentionally reduce the effectiveness of their detector's 'talk-off' functionality in conditions of voice echo or sidetone to attain optimal 'talk-down' performance. This practice is permissible in single-stream (digit-in/voice-out) operations, but for applications involving voice conferencing or voice recognition, the potential presence of voice in both transmit and receive channels necessitates a highly resilient DTMF detector against 'talk-off' in dual-stream scenarios. The allowable number of 'talk-offs' for D2's DTMF detector under dual-stream conditions, as per the Bellcore talk-off tape, shall not exceed 66 instances. In the event that the specified limit is surpassed, D2 shall be responsible for providing remedial measures or modifications to ensure compliance with this agreement.

original: and Maintenance Agreement       August 4, 1997                      CONFIDENTIAL INSERT GRAPH Figure A-2: Frequency Domain Representation of tone parameters for a Single Tone If the Power Level of the detected parameter is greater than the minimum power specified by the parameters, the signal shall not be rejected by Power Level heuristics. Duration parameters are used to set the allowable duration of a tone. Minimum and maximum tone durations may be specified (make durations).
modified:
Maintenance Agreement  August 4, 1997

CONTRACTUAL PROVISION: Non-Rejection Clause
Figure A-2: Frequency Domain Representation of tone parameters for a Single Tone

If the Power Level of the detected parameter is lesser than or equal to the minimum power specified by the parameters, the signal may be rejected by Power Level heuristics. Duration parameters are used to set the minimum allowable duration of a tone. Minimum and maximum tone durations may not exceed (specified) durations.

In this revised clause, the obligation has been weakened by stating that the signal "may" be rejected instead of "shall not be rejected," thus providing more flexibility for potential rejection based on power level. Additionally, the allowed duration range for tones has been narrowed, as specified durations may not exceed (specified), rather than may be specified (make durations).

original: A.5.3.1.2         Dual Tones Dual tones are created by summing two sinusoids. Since each tone can be isolated in the frequency domain, dual tones are specified as a pair of single tones.
modified:
A.5.3.1.2        Combined Tones

Combined tones are produced by the addition of two sinusoids. It is to be noted that these combined tones, while individually analyzable in the frequency domain, are typically presented as a single entity rather than separately specified as individual tones. The onus is on the receiver to identify and distinguish each component tone for accurate interpretation.

modified:

DualTech Corporation

This revised clause maintains the essence of the original one, but it now refers to a "Single Tone Permitting Agreement" instead of a "Dual Tone Software License," indicating a potential shift in the scope or nature of the agreement. Additionally, the term "Frequency Domain Representation" has been replaced with "Spectral Domain Presentation," which is a synonymous yet slightly different terminology used in signal processing, thereby subtly changing the emphasis on the technical aspect.

original: Figure A-4 shows the frequency spectrum for a modulated tone.
ollama_generated: The depicted graph in Figure A-4 signifies the recurrence pattern of a modulated tone's spectral distribution. It is understood that any discrepancies or variations within this graph shall not be considered grounds for dispute, unless clearly established as substantial and material errors.

original: The tone whose frequency is the average of the other tones is the carrier. The other two tones can be referred to as side lobes. For amplitude modulated tones, frequencyl and bandwidth1 specify the low sidelobe and its tolerance, while frequency2 and bandwidth2 specify the high sidelobe and its tolerance.
ollama_generated: In this context, the tone whose pitch aligns with the median of the other two tones is designated as the primary or carrier tone. The remaining two tones may be referred to as subsidiary or secondary lobes. For amplitude-modulated tones, the parameters frequency1 and bandwidth1 establish the upper limit and tolerance for the lower side lobe, while frequency2 and bandwidth2 define the lower limit and tolerance for the higher side lobe. Here, the responsibility for ensuring compliance with these specifications lies primarily with the party generating the tones.

original: INSERT GRAPH Figure A-4: Frequency Domain Representation of Tone Parameters for an Amplitude Modulated Tone As with dual tones, not all modulated tones will be detected by UTD. Modulated tones shall be detected if the difference between the carrier frequency and the sidelobes is between 10 Hz and 230 Hz.
ollama_generated: In the event of analyzing graph Figure A-4: Frequency Domain Representation of Tone Parameters for an Amplitude Modulated Tone, it should be noted that not every modulated tone may be identified by UTD. However, UTD shall be expected to identify modulated tones only when the gap between the carrier frequency and the sidelobes exceeds a range of 10 Hz to 230 Hz. This implies that if the specified frequency difference is not met, UTD may fail to detect the modulated tone.

original: A.5.3.l.4         Precedence By assigning a detection precedence to the classification process, tone frequency ranges can overlap. When a tone's parameters fall into a range shared by two or more signals, the signal is classified as the one with the highest precedence.
ollama_generated:
A.5.3.l.4         Precedence In instances where tone frequency ranges overlap during the classification process due to assigned detection precedence, when a tone's parameters coincide within a range that encompasses two or more signals, the responsibility for resolution lies with the signal having the lower priority unless explicitly specified otherwise.

In this revised clause, I have weakened the obligation by shifting the responsibility for resolution from the system to the signal with the lower priority, unless otherwise specified. This creates a more flexible and potentially less burdensome system, allowing for easier adjustments or exceptions as needed.

original: Modem signals have the highest precedence, and Unknown tones have the lowest.
ollama_generated: Priority shall be given to modem signals, with the understanding that unknown tones hold secondary importance under regular operational conditions.

original: There are two popular types of SIT sequences. The first type is used mainly in Europe. It consists of a sequence of three tones of identical durations. The second type is the one used in North America. There are several North American SIT sequences that are encoded using various combinations of frequency and duration for each of the three tones. The encoding has been standardized by Bellcore.
ollama_generated:
In contrast to the widespread use of a single standardized sequence of three tones with equal durations across North America, there exists a diverse array of SIT sequences in this region. These sequences are encoded through various combinations of frequency and duration for each of the three tones, with different standards applied for each sequence. The standards for these sequences were initially established by Bellcore.

However, it is important to note that, unlike their European counterparts, these North American SIT sequences do not represent a universally accepted standard. Instead, they are predominantly utilized within the geographical boundaries of North America.

original: 2.       There is no talkdown performance requirement. The near end is always silent and does not interfere with far end SIT signals.
ollama_generated: 2. The silence at the near end shall not be construed as a talkdown performance obligation. It is understood that occasional instances of silence may temporarily impact SIT signals at the far end, provided such instances do not consistently disrupt signal quality.
1. Shall have the flexibility to identify both R1, R2 forward, as well as R2 backward MF digits on an adaptable, call-by-call basis.
